title: Iain Macwhirter  Here s yet more evidence that Scots were played for fools in 2014
story: In the years leading up to the  referendum, Unionists never tired of warning Scots that independence would mean the loss of that great U.K. institution: the BBC. All that wee and poor Scotland would be able to afford would be wall-to-wall White Heather Club, interspersed with speeches from Alex Salmond.You can see where Irsquom going with this, canrsquot you :He acts the clown but Boris Johnson is a Bolshevik about powerThe former BBC Director-General, John Birt, said that Scots might not be able watch the BBC at all. Well, as it turns out perhaps no one will. At the weekend No Ten declared war on the BBC, saying that timersquos up for the licence fee.ldquoWersquore going to whack them, said a Government source, quoted in The Sunday Times. Probably been watching too many episodes of The Sopranos.The future is subscription. People wonrsquot pay a video poll tax in the age of Netflix, wersquore told. The BBC should sink or swim in the market ndash probably the former. First casualties will be local and ldquoregionalldquo servicesWersquore assured that this has nothing whatever to do with Andrew Neilrsquos lecture on the PMrsquos integrity when he refused to appear on his show during the General Election campaignNow, itrsquos not yet clear that the Government will get away with this. Many Tory MPs remain friends of the Beeb .Contrariwise, there are many independence supporters who hate the ldquoYoon BBC so much they are egging Mr Johnson on. There is a broad coalition of contempt for the BBC.This extends from most Labour Party members, who took to social media to condemn Laura Kuenssberg for being a Tory spokesperson, to the Daily , which believes the BBC is owned by Gina Miller and the Peoplersquos Vote campaign.It was ever thus. The BBC always gets both ideological barrels. But the point is that all this makes a nonsense of the claim that only by remaining in the UK could Scots still tune in to David Attenborough. Hersquos all over Netflix anyway.And the curious thing is that now there actually is a Scottish dedicated TV channel it is not filled with mawkish sentimentality and tartan kitsch. Most of the Scottishprogramming is rather good. Documentaries like Poverty Safari presented by the rapper Loki, for example ndash something the UK BBC would never have done.And therersquos quality. The drama Guilt was as good as anything on Netflix. Scotland has a unique character that is well suited to sardonic noir.The BBC is only the latest example of Scotland potentially losing great British institutions that were supposedly threatened onlywe voted Yes. Remember Royal Bank of Scotland saying that it would up sticks after independence Well, without a trace of irony, or self-awareness, RBS has just renamed itself the National Westminster Bank, in recognition of the fact that  per cent of its business is in the South.Another pillar of the Scottish financial sector, Standard Le, also threatened to leave Scotlandthere was a Yes vote in . It has now shted pound billion in assets to Dublin.Scots have a highly-developed sense of self-deprecating humour. Just as well. Because otherwise we might get very angryndash like those French demonstrators in Yellow Vests. Wersquore used to it. Like the weather.But yoursquod think that there would be just a hint of contrition from those nominally Scottish institutions which sought so recklessly to damage Scotlandrsquos reputation and national self-confidence five years agoRBS was already effectively a London bank in , with the majority of its operations in England. The threatened departure was contrived for political purposes.The same goes for Standard Le. Without a momentrsquos reflection, it has shted a number of operations to Ireland the better to remain in the European Union.I need hardly remind readers that Scots were told that only by voting No in , could Scotland be sure of remaining in the European Union. David Nish, the boss of Standard Le said almost exactly that. Many Scots believed him. When the history of Scottish independence is written, that will be up there with the poll tax and Margaret Thatcher.The list of broken referendum promises goes on and on. ldquoAs near a federal system as possible in the UK was how the former Labour PM, Gordon Brown, described the constitutional future should Scotland reject independence. That was the substance of The Vow published by the Daily Record, in cod vellum, and signed by all three UK party leaders.Well, the powers of Holyrood have been substantially curbed in the UK Withdrawal Act. The UK Government, when it can be bothered, insists that those powers over agriculture, fisheries, environment and so on will come winging back once Boris has Got Brexit Done.Anyone who believes that hasnrsquot been listening. Scotland will be allowed to administer these s, but standards will be set by the UK the better to facilitate trade deals with countries like America. Similarly, Michael Goversquos promise that Scotland would get powers over immigration after Brexit look ridiculous now.Itrsquos enough to make you want another referendum. Nicola Sturgeon keeps saying that Indyref will happen later this year. But that is a heroic case of hope triumphing over experience, or reality itself.The joke is on us. There wonrsquot be another legal referendum now that Mr Johnson is home with an -seat majority in Westminster.It feels ashistory itself is trolling Scotland, seeing just how much humiliation Scots are prepared to take.:Boris-induced surge evokes electric shock experimentEnglish people werenrsquot so docile and biddable. When Brexiters were confronted with Project Fear, they scoffed and voted regardless for what they regarded as independence from Brussels.Scots were given an offer they couldnrsquot refuse in : a borderless independence within Europe. Unfortunately, we did refuse it. And wersquore stuck with it.And herersquos the kicker. If Scotland had voted Yes, does anyone seriously think David Cameron would have staged that referendum on Brexit

title: Rosemary Goring  Why can t men dress properly nowadays
story: Football manager Pep Guardiola stared out: saturnine, grizzled, but above all terribly dressed. What was he thinking when he walked out the door  Did nobody call him back and suggest he change into something better  News of Manchester City being slapped with a two-year UEFA ban would have been at the forefront of his mind, I know, but thatrsquos no justication for his down-at-heel appearance. Did Emmanuel Macron arrive at work in a onesie when the gillets jaunes were torching Paris  Did Channel  presenter Jon Snow fling on any old tie or boring socks because it was Election Night But there was Guardiola in a baggy oatmeal fine-knit jumper that did his midrf no favours. That porridgy colour can be cruel, especially when, as in this case, it didnrsquot fit. The sleeves were long enough to double as skipping ropes. It was worn over a white teeshirt which, to be fair, was as white asstraight out of the wrapper, but his trousers were so faded and dreary no self-respecting charity shop would have put them in the window.Doubtless everything bore a designer label, but that means nothing. As I once discovered, it is entirely possible to enter an eye-wateringly pricey emporium and emerge from the changing rooms looking like a walking bin bag. Despite his position as one of the most prominent figures in sport, and with no financial constraints on his wardrobe, Guardiola chose that day ndash and many others ndash to look more like a sloppy teenager who has retrieved his stuff from the laundry basket for the third day running than a premier league manager and representative of the sporting elite.In this, I should quickly add, he is not alone. There are even stronger contenders for criticism, high among them the prime ministerrsquos consigliore, Dominic Cummings. Barely a day passes without an image of him scurrying past snappers in a symphony of greys and blacks, from beanie hat and tee-shirt, or creased, untucked shirt and low-slung jeans. Occasionally there is a flash of bright cashmere, accessorised with a plastic carrier bag.Long before Cummings advertised for weirdos and misfits to join him in Downing Street he had set a low dress-code bar, the sort intended ndash because it cannot be an accident ndash to convey disdain for conventional attire and standards. Such abject lack of stylishness might be acceptable in Silicon Valley or Deliveroo, but the message it sends is dismal. It also hints at menace, the attire of a dangerous lone wolf. Such slovenliness gives two fingers to the quaint idea that, when yoursquore at the heart of government, what you wear matters. If this is thinking outside the box, then Cummings has certainly nailed it.If yoursquore like me, you yearn for the days of Cary Grant. Gentlemenrsquos magazines in the s ran features on how to emulate his debonair outfits. But as everyone knows, while clothes maketh the man, some men maketh clothes look better than others. Grantrsquos Italian suits, fedora and glossy shoes gave him an almost regal presence. There was an artistry in the way he put things together, his raincoat draping around him in graceful folds ashe were a human waterfall, rather than bunched at the waist like a scarecrow. Dean Martin was another snappy dresser, as was Frank Sinatra, in his street-wise way, though for my taste he was a little too slick. When Columbo shrugged on his working unorm of ill-kempt Mac, he wanted suspects to think he was dim and harmless. They saw scruffy, and presumed stupid. To an extent, we all do.Sadly we donrsquot have too many sartorial icons here, although Sean Connery was never more striking than when the James Bond costume department got their hands on him. Thereafter, his preferred mode was that of a golfer who has accidentally strayed from the ninth hole. Ten or so years ago, one brave MSP friend publicly decried the national love of shell suits, only for the tabloid guns to be turned full-bore upon him. As a politician he stood out, among other things, for his fondness for plus fours and deerstalkers. I once gave him a lt, when I too was wearing tweed, and felt aswe had driven onto the set of Monarch of the Glen.It seems deeply unfair, though, that a man visibly and expensively supporting one of our noblest industries was taken to task for his loyalty. It was also unusual. Normally itrsquos women who are lambasted for committing minor or imaginary faux pas, people judging them, like books, entirely by their covers. In this, as in so many realms, men have got away lightly down the years. Perhaps that exemption should end.Itrsquos not that I care much what anyone wears. As a journalist, I learned to note down immediately what interviewees were wearing, otherwise later Irsquod completely forget. Nor have I ever been chic. Even I, however, can tell the dference between a well-dressed inidual and one who has gone out of his way to appear grungy and hip. Thatrsquos fine for the weekend, but not when yoursquore on the office clock. Mark Zuckerbergrsquos rail of unormly grey tee-shirts, to save him time choosing in the morning, set a terrible trend. Now Alpha males who aspire to rise beyond reach of the common ruck seem to equate a miserably relaxed style with a placard screaming lsquobillionairersquo or lsquopowerful beyond your wildest dreamsrsquo.The ever-suave George Clooney shows they are missing the point. A wedding guest who was told recently to remove his tie before he could attend the ceremony because ties are uncool, should have turned on his polished Oxford heel and left. Making a sartorial effort is a tangible way of expressing respect, not merely for yourself but for others. Emulating the kids, or pretending that casual clothes make no dference to your performance or the impression you make, is an older manrsquos delusion. A good suit and tie inspire confidence and trust, whatever your age. What baffles women is why, with such a simple formula for success ndash unlike the minefield of female fashion ndash there are still so many men dressing badly.

title: new-blue-passports-rolled-next-month

story: The airline boss has been accused of making ldquoracist and discriminatory remarks.The Muslim Council of Britain said the comments amounted to discrimination against Muslim passengers, while hate-crime monitoring group, Tell Mama suggested his ldquoflippant words could end up having serious consequences for the business.The -year-old told the Times that families with young children should be waved through airport security because there was ldquovirtually zero chance of them being bombers.Who are the bombers  They are going to be single males travelling on their own, he said.ldquoIf you are travelling with a family of kids, on you go the chances you are going to blow them all up is zero.He added: ldquoYou canrsquot say stuff, because itrsquos racism, but it will generally be males of a Muslim persuasion. Thirty years ago it was the Irish.ldquoIf that is where the threat is coming from, deal with the threat.A spokeswoman for the Muslim Council of Britain said: ldquoMichael OrsquoLeary should be under no illusion: his comments are racist and discriminatory.ldquoHe openly advocates discrimination against lsquomales of a Muslim persuasionrsquo, which presumably is not based on specic intelligence but solely whether someone lsquolooks or acts like a Muslimrsquo.ldquoThis is the very definition of Islamophobia.The spokeswoman said Muslims already face challenges in airline travel and added: ldquoIt is a shame that such racism is being expressed so openly, and that the CEO of a large airline would so want to discriminate against his customers so brazenly.Hate-crime monitoring group Tell Mama said the comments could come back to bite Mr OrsquoLearyrsquos business, likening them to jewellery firm boss Gerald Ratnerrsquos disastrous remark in  when he called one of his own products ldquototal Muslims are then Irsquod be very happy to learn from him ndash you canrsquot judge a book by its cover, he told the Times.He added: ldquoIn Germany this week a white person killed eight people.ldquoShould we profile white people to seetheyrsquore being fascists ldquoHersquos being very blinkered and is actually encouraging racism.Mr OrsquoLearyrsquos remarks came the day after a white female Muslim convert admitted plotting a suicide bomb attack on St Paulrsquos Cathedral in London.Safiyya Amira Shaikh, , was born Michelle Ramsden but converted to Islam in  and is believed to have become radicalised in  after following extremists online.The airline chief is no stranger to controversial remarks, particularly his comments on environmentalists and travel agents, using the title: calls-rural-pilot-scheme-go-ahead-catastrophic-immigration-policy-announcement
story: As revealed earlier this week, the UK is set to bring in a raft of new restrictions for migrants looking to work in the country, with those classed as low-skilled being given little opportunity to enter.Experts claimed Scotland would be worst hit, due to the demographic need for migrants to boost population growth and the employment challenges in rural areas.Westminsters own Migration Advisory Committeerecommended that a rural pilot scheme be introduced for parts of Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland to ensure migrants could still work in areas which "face more complex challenges in recruitment and retention of workers.The report released last month stated: "There should be a separate pilot visa for lsquoremotersquo areas of the UK, part of which could be lower salary thresholds for migrants into those areas. This should only be done with a full evaluation to understand its effectiveness and impacts.However in the policy revealed on Tuesday by Priti Patel, no mention of the scheme was made, prompting concern from Scottish business owners and politicians that it may not happen at all.The Scottish Government said it was deeply concerned that the proposals have not been mentioned since they were recommended by MAC, and demanded Westminster seriously consider its suggestions of implementing a Scottish visa.Some in the hospitality, tourism and agriculture sectors have already told of how the plans would cripple their businesses, with some firms employing % of their workers who are not from the UK.Home Secretary Patel said thatbusinesses foresee problems with the plan, they should automate their processes or find a dferent way of working, promoting further outcry up and down the country.The Scottish Governments Migration Minister Ben Macpherson has today reiterated the calls for a rural pilot scheme, and has urged Boris Johnsons Government to ensure it is in the policy before changes take effect in January .He said: "The Scottish Government and many others across the business community and the third sector have made it unequivocally clear to the UK Government that their immigration plans would deeply damage Scotlandrsquos economic, social and demographic prosperity.ldquoThe proposals would be catastrophic for rural areas, which are particularly dependent on migration to sustain local communities and public services, so it is deeply worrying that the UK Government does not appear to mention anywhere in these latest proposals their own prior commitment to running rural migration pilots.ldquoThe Scottish Government put forward a clear, workable proposal for devolving immigration powers and introducing a Scottish visa, which would allow Scotland to attract and retain people with the skills and attributes we need for all our communities and economy to flourish.ldquoThe UK Government must now seriously engage with these proposals, which have widespread support across Scotland.A Home Office spokesman told The Herald on Sunday there were several elements of the policy on immigration still being discussed, with further announcements to be made in the coming months.They could not confirmthe rural pilot schemes would be part of these announcements, but said that applying dferent immigration rules to dferent parts of the UK would overly complicate the immigration system and cause signicant dficulties for employers who need the flexibility to deploy their staff across the UK.A spokeswoman said: "The UK points-based immigration system will work in the interests of the whole country ndash Scotland included.ldquoIt will attract the brightest and the best from around the globe, boost the economy and our communities as well as ending free movement bringing overall migration numbers down.

title: rab-mcneil-back-stone-age-rubber-pavements-stodge-free-moaning-name-progress
story: ITrsquoS been another bad week for Extinction Rebellion , and thatrsquos good news for the planet.Most people accept scientic analysis of climate, which says the atmosphere is hotting up at an unsustainable rate, leading to deleterious meteorological phenomena. Wersquore all trying to do something, evenit feels like small beer, such as household recycling.This week, the Scottish National Blood Transfusion Service announced a ban on traditional cups of tea for donors as these arenrsquot ldquoenvironmentally friendly. The cups of tea, that is, not the donors . And itrsquos not the tea itself, but the polystyrene cups. Irsquom guessing good china canrsquot be used as they donrsquot have anyone to clean them. Itrsquos called progress. You wouldnrsquot understand.The transfusion service has a decent case, though a small voice whispers that itrsquos just a gesture, doing something to be seen to be doing something.Extra-parliamentary politics is all gesture, and they donrsquot come more full of jest than XR, widely slated this week for digging up lawns and creating a mess at the Home Office and Cambridge University to make a point that remains unclear.To say the least, digging up grass is not a good look for greens. It was such bad PR that one suspects theyrsquove engaged PR professionals.Therersquos more than a hint, too, in XR of middle-class larpersturning a serious crisis into cheap drama, taking leading parts for the cameras, dressing in red robes and looking like sententious priests from some weird interplanetary cult on Star Trek.Various predictions since the s averred wersquod all have boiled or frozen or starved to death by . All came to nought. And, going back through the centuries, you canrsquot help feeling XR is just the latest of these end-is-nigh cults that are a recurring phenomenon of hysteria in human history.Worse is to come for, already, there are people who feel XR isnrsquot going far enough. One such is Professor Patricia MacCormack, of Anglia Ruskin University, who says in her book, The Ahuman Manesto, that giving birth is ldquothe worst thing you can do to the climate.Irsquod some sympathy with this idea at first, until I realised it would lead to human extinction. And sure enough, according to the publisherrsquos publicity, the book ldquoembraces issues like human extinction, vegan abolition, atheist occultism, death studies, a refusal of identity politics, deep ecology, and the apocalypse as an optimistic beginning. Optimistic. I see.According to a review by Margrit Shildrick, guest professor of gender and knowledge productionat Stockholm University : ldquoAs a vegan abolitionist extinctionist, she [MacCormack] provides an unrelenting and exacting take-down of the violent self-interest of the human species ...Elsewhere, Prof MacCormack, who reportedly moonlights as a DJ, complains that the planetrsquos problems have been caused by ldquocreating this hierarchical world where white, male, heterosexual people are succeeding. Yes, terrible business.If this is your polystyrene cup of tea, you can find more on YouTube, where Patricia, or Morticia as shersquos been dubbed, partly for her Goth appearance, discusses ldquovulvic demaonitalia, which I donrsquot need to tell you invokes ldquodemonic convocation as an important ethical feminist and queer practice.Jeez. Tell you what: people of my vintage feel partly responsible for all this nutterism. We marched for womenrsquos rights, gay rights, Greenpeace . Now behold the monster wersquove created.The progressivism we championed is progressing us back to the stone age. Itrsquos like a big mad ball that keeps gaining momentum until itrsquos out of control and bouncing back towards us for a spectacular own goal.Fall and rise of bouncing OAPsHERErsquoS something we should have thought of before to help personkind on its way: rubber pavements. Scientists are developing new sidewalk surfaces made from recycled tyres.The purpose is to reduce injuries among pensioners, who have a bizarre habit of falling to the ground. It says here that one in three OAPs takes a tumble each year in Britain, with many suffering hip fractures.But Professor Cesare Sangiorgi, from the University of Bologna, says: ldquo[If] people fall on our pavement, they are less likely to suffer injuries because the severity of the fall will be substantially reduced. It can reduce the burden on the health service.Too right. Apparently, falls cost the NHS pound. billion a year, which of course isnrsquot a true figure but the usual public spending fiction. All the same, falls must cost the service a pretty penny.The new pavement is to be piloted in Sweden, where old people are considered expendable and often used in experiments.No one is denying that old people should buck up their ideas when out walking but, since this is unlikely to happen soon, anything that helps them bounce back on their feet is welcome.Bacterial ersity a no-brainerAW, so to speak, naw. Yet again, wersquore being told to eat a Mediterranean diet, which consists of appalling rubbish like tomatoes, olive oil and garlic, the very thought of which is enough to make decent Britons gag.The new sales pitch is that the Med diet stems the loss of bacterial ersity ndash yawn ndash delaying the onset of frailty in old age and protecting brain , something thatrsquos always been over-rated in my experience.Itrsquos not just top complainers like me moaning about this alien cuisine, with its cheerless lack of stodge. Online, leading intellectuals said you had to live in a Mediterranean country for it to work and that it wasnrsquot suitable for a joyless dreich joint like Scotland.Sunshine in particular was adduced as a key ingredient for long le, though scientic evidence suggests it boils the brain and leads to instability. For clarication: not scientic evidence but informed guesswork .After a while, to be frank, it gets irritating to keep reading that everybody  is eating right except us and that we deserve to die for our homely, comforting fare. At least we might expire happy rather than gagging on garlic or choking on vexatious legumes.

title: living-caves-moving-primarily-night-40-years-david-pratt-afghanistan
story: Pratt observes: ldquoItrsquos  years that country has been at war. There are kids that I was with in the early s whotheyrsquore still alive will not have known one day of peace. Anwarirsquos son is -ish and hersquos never known it. It was the th anniversary of the Soviet invasion on Christmas day. ##Readers of this paper, The Herald on Sunday, The Herald and the former Sunday Herald will be familiar with Prattrsquos extraordinary photojournalism and reports from war-torn parts of the world ndash Iraq, Gaza, Syria, Somalia, Democratic Republic of Congo, Bosnia.The title of a recent exhibition of his photographs, Only With The Heart, was taken from a quote by Antoine de Saint-Exupery: ldquoIt is only with the heart that one can see rightly, what is essential is invisible to the eye.There are few journalists with more heart, or more commitment to the stories they report on. The focus of this first documentary about his work is Afghanistan because itrsquos a country he has been visiting for over four decades. Itrsquos where a piece of his heart is. ##The idea, he tells says, of reporting from Afghanistan first entered his imagination when he was lying in a bed in a hospital in Nicaragua, feverish with malaria, after he had gone out there, just out of art school, to cover the revolution.As he suffered in the stling heat, he came across a copy of National Geographic with Steve McCurryrsquos iconic image of a young Afghan woman on the cover.ldquoI flicked through and I remember the pictures were of snowy mountains in Afghanistan ndash and I was sweltering in this hospital from malaria and, God, it looked so inviting almost by contrast, he recalls. ##Pratt wasnrsquot a stereotypical war reporter from a privileged background. He was a working-class boy who had grown up in the Hillhouse scheme near Hamilton, which, he says, they used to call ldquoBeirut or Hellhouse. The first time he was ever shot at, he describes, was in the street there, when he was seven years old and someone ldquotook a pot shot at the postman who had failed to deliver his giro benefit cheque, and he happened to be walking nearby.##His background is one of the things that makes his early trips all the more remarkable. ldquoWorking-class people were not meant to do what I was doing, he says. ldquoEvery foreign correspondent at that time was middle or upper class. There were times when I didnrsquot have the #price of a tube fare to come in from my flat in the southside of Glasgow for meetings in the city centre, but I was planning to go to Afghanistan in a few weeksrsquo time.ldquoYou would beg, borrow and steal to get the money to get to these places. I feltI ended up getting clobbered in Afghanistan at least theyrsquore not going to come looking for my overdraft. There was a degree of fate about it.##Pratt was looking out at the world at a particular political moment ndash the early s, following the revolution in Nicaragua, the Iranian revolution, and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, all of which had taken place in . ldquoAfghanistan wasnrsquot really known at that time, he recalls. ldquoIt was still an obscure backwater. The only thing yoursquod read about it was the hippy trail. But the politics of the region werenrsquot known.ldquoThe religious aspect of it was misunderstood. A lot of the mujahideen groups were Islamist, but they werenrsquot absolutely rabid fundamentalists like the Taliban. They just didnrsquot like the bloody Russians. And can you blame them ##Pratt didnrsquot head out there looking for a specic story ndash though he had an interest in guerrilla movements and underdogs. ldquoI wasnrsquot looking at the grand politics of things, he says. ldquoI was very interested in how people lived. Although the irony is that by the stage I went to Afghanistan, I was very left-wing. I was actually a card-carrying member of the communist party.ldquoIf the mujahideen had known I was a communist it would have been curtains. They wouldnrsquot have waited to find out that I was interested in the notion of resistance and guerrilla movements.##His route into Afghanistan involved illegally crossing the border from Pakistan. The way Pratt tells it, it sounds like after a small amount of research. He flew to Peshawar on a wing and a prayer ndash with few connections. ldquoAfghanaid was my first port of call in Peshawar and they kind of sent me in the direction of one or two mujahideen, but I had to make those approaches myself.##What strikes you almost immediately is how risky his forays into Afghanistan were. He travelled with small groups of mujahideen, slept in caves, moved at night, and, when he fell ill, which he did, would have to be smuggled back out of the country. Often the groups he was with were making -hour marches through the Hindu Kush.He was also highly dependent on the mujahideen guerrillas who took him into the country, people like Sayed Anwari, with whom he formed a close friendship. ldquoWithout them, it would have been impossible. I went back and forward across the border in all these dferent guises. I got caught dressed as a woman in a burka. I went in a coffin, behind grain sacks. Anwari would organise these elaborate ways of getting in and out. I was completely dependent on them.##His le was at risk on countless occasions. In the film, he describes one occasion when he and the group he was with had to beat a retreat from mortar bombardment. ldquoRounds were landing all around you ndash people were going into the air, pieces of them coming off, body parts everywhere.As he and the others around him ran, he passed a man whose knee had been blown off. The man put his hand out asto ask for help, but shells were still landing all around him and he had to run on. ldquoThere is a kind of guilt about that, Pratt says in the film.##You canrsquot help but wonder what his parents and friends must have been thinking. In those times,you travelled in remote areas, you were essentially dropping off the map, cutting all connection with home. ldquoThere were no mobile phones, he says. ldquoThere was no contact. Some of the trips were months on end, and you would cross the border illegally into Afghanistan and disappear off the radar. I might never have come back. ##His parents however, were already used to these disappearances. At  years old, already a keen mountaineer, he was hitchhiking to Glencoe, sleeping under bridges and tackling serious rock-climbing routes. ldquoI was already doing that, so the idea of prolonged absences was no shock to my parents, he says.##The assumption when he was growing up had always been that he would join the military. ldquoIt was a very male-dominated family, says Pratt. ldquoMy uncles were in the military. My father had done his national service in the Middle East. That upbringing instilled in him ldquoan urge to see the world. He goes on: ldquoThe military may have been a way of doing that, but in the end I got really politically opposed to things military. ##Instead he did ldquothe polar opposite and went to Glasgow School of Art, and that was where his journey towards documentary photography began. ldquoSome of my close student friends could see my increasing interest in documentary work. They were seeing a drt towards the political and the fact that a painting was too contemplative for me. The camera was a more immediate tool.##Pratt made scores of trips into Afghanistan during the s. Some were for only two or three days, but his longest was for over three months.What does he think he learned in those early years ldquoIt was mostly finding out about myself, he says. ldquoIt was physically and psychologically very hard. I was on my own. You would be three months in the mountains. My interpreter was a young engineering student from Kabul University who did not want to be a guerilla and didnrsquot want to be hoofing over the Hindu Kush mountains, so when he was given the task by Anwari he actually loathed me because Irsquod got him into this situation. We became great friends. So those long hikes over the mountains were finding out about ourselves.##Pratt kept going back to Afghanistan even after the Soviet withdrawal in . ldquoFrom the s, the mujahideen were bickering among themselves, he recalls. ldquoIt was horrendous and the West was not really interested. I was determined to cover it simply because it wasnrsquot getting covered. No-one was interested now it was Afghans fighting Afghans, not Afghans fighting the Communists any more.##Afghanistan remains war-torn, a precarious and unstable democracy. What happens there is little talked about in the West ndash a recent New York Times editorial described it as ldquoThe Unspeakable War. Meanwhile, the Taliban wages violence and controls many parts of the country.In the documentary, Pratt talks with a Taliban leader by telephone, and is told that peace will only be possible in Afghanistanthe barriers to it are lted ndash and that this would ldquorequire all foreign troops to leave Afghanistan. In recent days that possibility has come closer with the announcement from the Taliban that they are on the threshold of a historic agreement with the USA which would involve withdrawal of troops.##During his film, Pratt s to many of the frontlines from which he reported. The zoo, the site of his startling  image of a sheep wandering across a background of rubble and armoured tank, now feels like a bustling attraction in any city. But, he says, Kabul remains a scary place. When his documentary team visited the Puli Mahmood Kahn district, another former frontline, they were told by their security officers that people up the street were making calls on their mobile phones.ldquoThat area is Taliban central. We bundled into the car and shot off. We had to get up the street and we did a right on to the main highway and the security guy told the driver to do a complete U-turn in the middle of the street and then go back the other way because otherwise the Taliban could ambush us further on. Yoursquore living with that all the time in Kabul.##Pratt went on to cover conflicts in many other parts of the world. The longer he went out for, he says, the harder it would be to adjust. ldquoAfter I was kidnapped in Bosnia, I went to ground for about six months.He also found it hard sometimes to be sympathetic when people back home were stuck on petty concerns.ldquoI remember coming back from Nicaragua, says Pratt. ldquoI was really quite sick and there was a woman on the last leg from Madrid to London and all she went on about was whether the driver she had would be waiting for her at Heathrow airport. Three days earlier Irsquod been in a refugee camp and Irsquod watched them put a machine gun in an adjacent area and fire on the refugees in the camp. Itrsquos dficult not to get angry. But peoplersquos problems are relative. ##For Pratt, the process of making the documentary has been ldquocathartic. The story it tells is of world events, but also his own le. Part of it happens back home, in Glasgow, with his partner, Caron, who has stuck with him through his repeated disappearances ndash a fact he says is ldquoamazing. Recently, he says, he overheard Caron talking about how miserable he was because he was waiting for a visa to go out to Iraq. If hersquos not there when something is happening, she observes, hersquos always miserable.ldquoI remember talking to Marie Colvin about that, he says. ldquoMarie was the worstsomething was happening where. Even when she was on a job she was thinking of the next job. Anditrsquos a part of the world yoursquore really familiar with ndash Afghanistan or Israel-Palestine ndash itrsquos twice as bad. ##Did he ever think about doing anything   ldquoNot really. Once I got into it that was it. The experience of arriving in Nicaragua at dawn, swaying palm trees, and humidity and crickets. Straight out of Graham Greene. Wonderful. You canrsquot go back from that, really. #####The Glasgow Film Festival premiere screening of Pictures From Afghanistan followed by a QA with David Pratt, chaired by Allan Little, is at the Glasgow Film Theatre on Sunday, March , at .pm. Tickets available on the GFF website

title: bbc-licence-fee-really-fit-21st-century
story: Nor is the question about whether you believe the BBC holds some sacred position in British society ndash like the NHS ndash or whether you want the sacred cow slain.The question is posed purely in terms of the enjoyment ndash the worth, the value, the fun ndash you get from the BBC. As a consumer, a viewer, a punter, a critic, does the BBC mean much to you any more  Long gone are the days when the BBC was basically all we had and so by default was the centre of cultural le. Wersquore media-rich now, and time-poor.When you weigh the BBC, and judge it, does the broadcaster ndash as its founder Lord Reith promised it would do ndash still ldquoinform, educate and entertain you  Andit does, is the BBC doing it better than its many rivals Our crowded broadcasting landscape means therersquos no longer a place for BBC exceptionalism. It has to earn its place like everyone . Among  to -year-olds, the BBC struggles to remain relevant. Less than half of that key demographic watch it, boding ill for the future.The BBCrsquos back is against the wall. In our increasingly ided society, people of all political persuasions believe the channel is partisan. The left and right both hate it. Hardline Scottish nationalists and hardline Brexiters detest the BBC ndash itrsquos either part of a treacherous pro-union conspiracy, or in league with Brussels.After the criticism Boris Johnson rightly got for dodging tough interviews during the General Election, the Prime Minister seems ready to come for the BBCrsquos licence fee now. Therersquos speculation about it being replaced with an opt-in subscription model like Netflix.Of course, given that this is Britain in , the debate around the BBCrsquos future will degenerate into yet another front in our endless culture wars and produce much heat but little light ndash like a s TV set.One side will say that any threat to the BBC will see Britainrsquos media landscape turn American, with right-wing propagandists fronting channels like Fox News. The other side will say the BBC is unfairly propped up by taxpayers to the detriment of other media outlets, skewing British cultural le.The future of the BBC will be determined on purely political grounds ndash which is very strange. The BBC must be the only media institution in any democracy which is judged by a political yardstick. Everything  in the media landscape ndash radio, print, cinema, TV, online ndash is judged on much more simple criteria: do people like it and are they happy to pay for it So letrsquos judge the BBC on purely critical grounds. Letrsquos set aside the political wrangle ndash and letrsquos address this central question:the broadcaster vanished tomorrow, would you care in terms of the value and entertainment it brings you As the screw began tightening on the BBC, Irsquove started to monitor my own consumption of its programming. I wanted to see just how important it was in my le. Would I be happy without it I was unpleasantly surprised to find that the BBC plays a much smaller role in my le than I thought. Full disclosure: Irsquove worked for the BBC, and Irsquom also one of those liberal types who has spoken of the BBC as an essential pillar of British le. So, I thought when I began studying my own viewing and listening habits, that given my background the BBC would be both the journalistic and entertainment mainstay of my le. Itrsquos not.My household is media-hungry. We take nearly every TV service there is: terrestrial TV, Netflix, Amazon Prime, Sky TV, Apple TV. Wersquove got Alexas in most rooms so we can listen to radio. The house is filled with books, newspapers and magazines. Wersquore happy to pay for media.However, the question is then raised: am I happy with the way Irsquom required to pay for the BBC, compared to how I pay for other media  Would the public be better servedwe could choose the parts of the BBC we wish to pay for These questions come increasingly into focus for me as I find the BBC taking up an ever diminishing sliver of my le. The same seems to be true for many other members of the public.Just look at whatrsquos happening with the BBCrsquos news channel. Of all the services the corporation provides, this is the one I most respect. Itrsquos dependable, impartial, informative. However, like the BBCrsquos drama and comedy output, which is threatened by both homegrown competitors Channel  and international media such as Netflix, the news service is under pressure from viewers consuming current affairs online via sites like Facebook.The reach of the BBC News channel is declining. In the second quarter of , it had  million viewers. Five years previously, there were  million.When it comes to the most popular TV channel, as of September , it was Channel  with a % positivity rating. BBC was second with %, then ITV with %.I find myself agreeing with the public. Itrsquos been a long time since Irsquove watched the BBCrsquos Six OrsquoClock News. I wait for Channel  news at pm. Itrsquos smarter, more international, more in-depth. If I had to pick the channel I get most value from itrsquos Channel . But Channel  isnrsquot put on a pedestal. It provides public service broadcasting and itrsquos commercially self-funded.Irsquod certainly miss BBC Newsnight, in particular the reporting of Emily Maitlis, televisionrsquos best journalist. As to the rest of BBC TVrsquos news and current affairs therersquos not much I couldnrsquot live without. Irsquod certainly survive without the clickbait of Question Time. In Scotland, STVrsquos Scottish news is as good,not better, than BBC Scotland.Radio is a dferent matter. Irsquom very fond of BBC radio. I love Radio  music, I like a bit of Radio rsquos Jo Whiley in the background when Irsquove chores to do, and Irsquom a Radio  fan. One programme Irsquod really miss is Radio rsquos In Our Time with Melvyn Bragg ndash the best and cleverest talk show ever made, I reckon. If the BBC vanished, though, could I happily survive on podcasts and commercial radio, which I find myself increasingly listening to  Probably.The one part of the BBC Irsquod hate to lose is BBC Four. Its documentary output is excellent. From populist history shows fronted by Lucy Worsley and the channelrsquos Friday night music documentaries, to erudite and in-depth explorations of art and science, BBC Four ndash for me at least ndash fulfils the pledge to educate, entertain and inform. Butthe BBC was to disappear, alternatives do exist ndash Sky Arts and a plethora of documentary channels.However, BBC Four is the broadcasterrsquos least-watched channel. In , BBC One had a reach of  million, Channel   million, BBC Two  million, Channel   million, ITV  million. BBC Four had a reach of  million, putting it in the same fighting weight as ITV and Dave.Perhaps thatrsquos because the upstart Netflix has got into documentaries in a big way. The BBCrsquos Storyville strand was once the gold standard of TV documentary making, but these daysyou want to watch an Oscar-winning documentary, or a documentary thatrsquos going to show you things yoursquove never seen before, then Netflix is the place to go. And, of course, therersquos Channel rsquos acclaimed factual output as well, which also easily rivals the BBC.The most remarkable water-cooler documentary of the last year was Tell Me Who I Am on Netflix ndash charting the story of the lives of two adult male twins, one of whom had lost their memory, while the other lived with the knowledge of the history of abuse they had suffered as children.For me, itrsquos BBC One I could really do without. I find its drama output poor, its light entertainment toe-curling. For light entertainment, I head to Channel . If I want something relatively mindless, Irsquoll opt for Gogglebox or First Dates rather than Strictly Come Dancing.In terms of BBC drama, even Line Of Duty or Bodyguard ndash which critics responded to asShakespeare had risen from the grave ndash are in my opinion just cliche-riddled cop shows.If I want original drama then Irsquoll likely turn to Channel  once again, or Netflix, Amazon Prime or Sky with their streaming box sets. You donrsquot get great long-form TV drama on the BBC. A series like Killing Eve is a rarity. HBO is the global hub of the best TV drama, with a pedigree of refined and intelligent programming like The Wire, Six Feet Under and The Sopranos.If you want to watch a great blockbuster series like Game Of Thrones ndash also from HBO ndash then yoursquore more likely to find it on Sky Atlantic than the BBC. A new comedy  Netflix is where Irsquoll look.Therersquos something quintessentially middle-class, middle-aged and middle-brow about BBC drama and comedy. If you distilled BBC drama down into one show it would probably look like Last Tango In Halax. Itrsquos a family saga set in Yorkshire. Itrsquos relatively entertaining, a sort of Cold Feet meets All Creatures Great And Small. Itrsquos cosy ndash as edgy as a butter kne.Channel  drama reflects British le back to viewers in a much more sophisticated way, while Netflix takes you all over the world in a kaleidoscope of genres. Therersquos German thrillers, French horror, Brazilian sci-fi, Belgium cop shows, American comedies, Israeli spy dramas. Itrsquos unusual for me now to watch a long-running show unless itrsquos on Netflix.For films, we never choose the BBC or any other terrestrial channel. We search Sky Cinema, Netflix and Amazon. Why wait until pm to watch a movie on the BBC when you can stream the same movie right now from another service No-one in my house is that interested in sport, but itrsquos how wersquove chosen to opt out of sports programming thatrsquos important, in terms of how the BBC offers its services. With our household Sky package wersquove said no to the sports subscription. Our children are now adults, so wersquove long cancelled the subscription to kidsrsquo programming. Wersquove modelled our Sky subscription around what we like as a family: drama, comedy, films and documentaries.Choice is often hugely overrated ndash just think of all those hours yoursquove spent scrolling through Netflix trying to find something to watch but bewildered by choice. However, flexibility in choosing what you pay for is only fair. Sky understands that I donrsquot like sport so makes it possible for me to buy the bits I want, and discard the bits I donrsquot. The BBC doesnrsquot get it ndash yet.Why canrsquot I pay for the BBCrsquos documentaries, its quizzesand radio ndash and dump the rest  I donrsquot want soaps, terrible Saturday night shows, and mediocre dramas. Irsquom also happy to pay for BBC news. The full-spectrum hatred that BBC news gets proves that in terms of journalism itrsquos doing its job.However, the rest of the BBCrsquos output isnrsquot for me. So reduce my licence fee accordingly. Netflix and Sky have flexible packages, why not the BBC  A flexible BBC subscription fee doesnrsquot immediately mean an end to all Government support. Some state funding could remain. But thatrsquos another discussion.From April, the licence fee will be pound. a year. Make my payment proportional to my consumption. If I want to opt into everything, fine, charge me the full pound.. If I want a slimmed-down package, then charge me a fair share. Netflix, for example, charges for three dferent packages: Basic at pound. per month, Standard at pound., and Premium at pound..Unlike every other media outlet, the BBC doesnrsquot woo me for my money, it demands my money. The others earn it, they persuade me to part with my cash ndash and they donrsquot have the law on their side threatening court.I always thought Irsquod remain a loyal BBC subject. But Irsquom starting to rebel. I donrsquot want to be a subject any longer. Irsquod like to take control of what I pay for. So, in answer to the question I posed myself ndash does the BBC really matter  ndash Irsquom increasingly leaning towards the answer: sadly, less and less.The media landscape has changed ndash but the BBC hasnrsquot. The result is that while once I truly thought I couldnrsquot imagine a world without the BBC, Irsquom coming to the unhappy conclusion that although I wouldnrsquot want to do without the BBC completely,I had to give it up, I could as there are plenty of good alternatives out there now.The only way the BBC can win back people like me is for the broadcaster to change and enter the st century before itrsquos too late.

title: jimmy-reid-inside-mind-working-class-hero
story: JIMMY Reid was haunted by memories of desperate poverty all his le. His early childhood in the Glasgow Gorbals slums, where three of his sisters died in infancy, drove him to fight to improve the lot of working-class people.Born into severe poverty in , Reid was drawn to radical politics as a way to bring about social reform, his heroic efforts for social change earning him the title ldquothe best MP Scotland never had.His passion and charisma, allied to a fearless ability for public speaking, made people from all walks of le sit up and listen ndash eventhey didnrsquot necessarily agree with him.Now a new biography traces Reidrsquos remarkable le from a poverty-stricken background in Glasgow to being thrown into the national limelight as the spokesman for the Upper Clyde Shipbuildersrsquo work-in.The authors of Jimmy Reid: A Clyde-built Man, who will be appearing at the Aye Write! festival next month, interviewed family members, friends and comrades, as well as delving into the University of Glasgow archives to shed new light on how Reid became a symbol of working-class defiance.ldquoWe were bowled over by the audacity of the Upper Clyde Shipbuilders shop stewards and by Reidrsquos role as leader and political icon in his own right, and he was arguably one of the greatest political orators since , said Dr William Knox, honorary senior lecturer in Scottish history at the University of St Andrews.His co-author, Professor Alan McKinlay, professor of human resource management at Newcastle University Business School, said: ldquoI was a schoolboy when the UCS work-in happened between  and , and we were one of the schools that collected money for the shipyard workers.ldquoMy dad worked at Rolls-Royce and, like the UCS men, had faced redundancy, and I admired these audacious men who stood up to market forces.Researching the book uncovered some startling revelations about the man who, along with fellow shop stewards Jimmy Airlie, Sammy Gilmore and Sammy Barr, led and won a major industrial struggle.For McKinlay, one of the most striking aspects of Reidrsquos le that emerged from the research was how intensely personal his politics were.ldquoThe image that stayed in my mind was of Jimmy as a young boy watching his father cradle his dying sister in his arms just as midnight struck on Hogmanay and Auld Lang Syne rang out in the streets outside, he said.To Reid, his three infant sisters ldquohad been murdered ndash whatever it said in the death certicate, they should have put down lsquosocial conditionsrsquo as the cause.ldquoHis visceral personal politics came down to this bedrock of morality, said McKinlay.ldquoIt was the devastating impact of poverty and the desire to eradicate it that shaped his politics from an early age, he added. ldquoEven in his last years he never ceased to be emotional when the bells rang out to announce the arrival of the New Year.When the family moved to Govan, their circumstances improved and Reid did well at St Gerardrsquos Senior Secondary, where he was streamed for university and read widely. Once asked by Jonathan Miller, the theatre director, at which university hersquod been educated Reid told him: ldquoGovan public library.Despite his obvious intelligence, Reid left school at  as his ldquoexpectations never involved higher education. I did not know anybody who went to university from the streets of Govan, he would say.Knox was struck by Reidrsquos contradictory nature ndash a product of the macho culture of the shipyards who loved cricket and played the saxophone.ldquoI was surprised to learn that Reid started his working le in a stockbrokerrsquos office, where his employer recognised his ability, said Knox.The young communist firebrand struck up a rapport with the senior partner who promised him a bright career as a future partnerhe stayed on, but Reidrsquos socialist convictions were incompatible with working in a stockbroking firm.However, this early training proved invaluable as it gave him an understanding of the workings of finance capital. He said: ldquoIrsquove always been able to read the stock exchange, and in debates with people it has become quite useful.Reid signed up as an engineering apprentice in the Govan shipyards, but the Scottish shipping industry was already in decline. There were  shipyards on the Clyde in  but by  only nine remained.In , the Heath government attempted to close Upper Clyde Shipbuilders, which had been merged from five yards.Refused further state support, UCS was forced into liquidation despite the yards having a full order book and a forecasted profit for . The shop stewards, including Reid, came up with the idea of a work-in rather than a strike, which would hand victory to the government.They would have ldquocheered us out of the yards, said Reid. ldquoIf we go out on strike, once wersquore out on the street, theyrsquoll padlock the gates. Wersquoll have done their job for them.ldquoThe University of Glasgow archives gave us access to tape recordings of the shop stewardsrsquo private meetings, said McKinlay. ldquoThey were very conscious that what they were doing was unprecedented, and that they were taking on a huge burden that they couldnrsquot mess up.ldquoThe humour of these men really came through ndash that rough, caustic Glasgow humour. People often underestimated Reid because of this sense of humour, and when they heard his accent. But behind all that was an intellect and a breadth of learning.Reidrsquos intelligence and oratorical powers came to the fore during the work-in, and his electrying address to the workforce became famous: ldquoTherersquos a basic elementary right invoked here ndash thatrsquos our right to work. Wersquore no strikers. We are responsible people and we will conduct ourselves with dignity and discipline. There will be no hooliganism. There will be no vandalism. There will be no bevvying, because the world is watching us.The subsequent government climbdown was viewed as a tremendous victory, but the responsibility for saving the livelihoods of thousands of families took its toll on Reid, who was twice admitted to hospital. His daughter Eileen told the authors he was ldquopublic property ... we hardly ever saw him ... our whole lives were taken over ... no normal stuff like going to the swimming baths.His widow Joan said: ldquoHe always whistled coming up the stairs. Andhe wasnrsquot whistling then you knew something was wrong. He never whistled during the work-in.Despite being a household name after helping to save around , jobs, Reid was rejected when he stood as an MP for Central Dunbartonshire. He left the Communist Party but was also defeated in Dundee East as a Labour candidate in  by the SNP and began a career as a columnist and broadcaster. Disillusioned by New Labour, he resigned from the party in  and joined the SNP in .When Reid died in , Govan shipyard workers lined the road as his cortege went past. At his funeral, former Prime Minister Gordon Brown said: ldquoThe fact there is still a shipbuilding industry in Scotland today is in large measure because of the inspirational campaigns that he waged.McKinlay said: ldquoIf his le had a message it was that morality rather than economics should be the bedrock of policymaking.bullWilliam Knox and Alan McKinlay will discuss Jimmy Reid: A Clyde-built Man at Aye Write! on Sunday, March  at pm.

title: climate-comment-can-bit-meet-net-zero
story: A ldquoclimate emergency needs a robust response. According to the philosopher Peter Springer, developed countries like the UK have an ethical duty to lead the world out of this crisis. After all, the UK has been partially responsible for creating the problem through its past actions. Much of its financial and intellectual capital base has been constructed on a legacy of environmental damage. It needs to put this right.The UK Government is committed to taking the country to net zero by  following the Committee on Climate Changersquos recommendation and analysis of the pathways to net zero. But the committee was also clear that there are huge policy challenges associated with meeting this objective.One of the most sobering aspects of the report from the Committee on Climate Change is the fact that we need to decarbonise the economy across all sectors simultaneously. It isnrsquot good enough to think we can do a little bit of this and then a little bit of that. The scale of this challenge is truly daunting not just for those who need to plan and implement these changes but for every single citizen. This will affect everybodyrsquos le. As I have said before, there is no point putting a bung in the tail pipe of a metaphorical car to stop its emissions without re-engineering, and perhaps even re-imagining, the car itself.Even though government has established a clear national objective, nobody should imagine that this is someone rsquos problem. It is not, as often implied, for government alone to deliver the changes which are needed. The government needs to play its part but there is a job for everybody and for every organisation and business. For example,every decision we make, from buying food in the local supermarket to deciding where to go on holiday, was informed by information about the environmental costs of the dferent options, we could probably make a massive and instantaneous dference. Many people already do this when deciding how much meat they eat, but this is just a start. Even small, almost imperceptible nudges to our decisions could be transformative. Government need to make sure we all have this information and, once delivered, we all have an ethical duty to take it into account.This is why I have taken on the job of leading the aspiration of the University of St Andrews to reach net zero in its own business within the time scales set by government. This university has adopted net zero as part of its strategy and make it a corporate responsibility. My job is to hold it to account and help it to reach its objective.Like any organisation, the university is going to find this dficult. It has already done much to reduce its carbon footprint, but there is only so much it can do on its own. Carbon, and other environmental impacts like water use, permeate almost everything the university does. Wringing the carbon and water out is going to take determination, smart decision-making and imaginative business practice.A university has a special role in the mission to achieve net zero. Apart from being an exemplar to normal businesses, it moulds the future through the research it does and the people it trains. It has global influence through its networks of academics and can itself be a living laboratory for exploring the kind of actions and technical fixes which demonstrate feasibility. A university is not just a crucible for the creation of new ideas but also an integrated part of delivering these ideas to meet the national objectives. It has an opportunity to create impact which is much greater than its size.Sir Ian Boyd is a professor of biology at the University of St Andrews and former Chief Scientic Adviser at the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

title: eastenders-anniversary-35-years-hatches-matches-dispatches-rebirths-shape-shifting
story: A cynic might say the comebacks occur when either the scriptwriters have run out of plotlines or the actors, who set out chasing that Hollywood role, stage or music opportunity, realise that their bread, thick white sliced, is better buttered in Albert Square.Some, of course, never reappear because, that cynic again, their ratings or focus group visibility doesnrsquot cut it.With  deaths in the place since the launch in , the Square is surely the most hazardous place on Earth, more dangerous than Chicago in the thirties or Caracas today. There have been stabbings, shootings, explosions, enforced plummets from high buildings, suicides, stranglings, squashings by lorry and car ndash this is a recurrent one ndash as well as natural causes like cancer, electrocution, speedboat accidents and heart attacks.But spare a thought for the novel ending of the poor sisters Roxy and Ronnie, the former dying of a heart attack in a pool and her sis drowning after she ed in to rescue her then her wedding dress pulled her down.What next  Well, Dot Cotton has disappeared from the Square, but will she be back  Not according to -year-old actor June Brown, who says her departure is ldquofor good. So, another demise could be on the horizon ndash and it might be a chance for writers to dream up something new. Irsquom putting my money on, not lung cancer, but that shersquos the first British-based victim of coronavirus, the cast in faces masks, her absence from the screen of late down to that quarantine period.Looking at the hatches, matches and dispatches, there have been more deaths than either marriages or births, so in another  years itrsquos possible that the last EastEnder croaks dramatically. Irsquom hoping itrsquos Ian Beale.The latest marriage ndash there have been  of them ndash was between Keegan Baker and Tfany Butcher. Tfany is Rickyrsquos daughter, possibly. Ricky is one who left, ed and left again. He was last spotted on Celebrity MasterChef, but fortunately none of the other contestants died.There has been a same-sex marriage. And Ian Beale, him again, has married almost all the female cast ndash five at the last count. Coming up on the rails, however, is Phil Mitchell with four, andthe latest, Sharon, isnrsquot careful she may end up in a rain butt behind the Queen Vic pub.Itrsquos the third one for Shaz. She used to be married to Philrsquos brother, Grant ndash are you keeping up  ndash who has left Walford to try to understand and make a crust from violent criminals the world over. He might have started by looking at his own brother.Phil has come and gone so often through the revolving door of the Square that it has all become a blur. Perhaps he makes himself scarce to evade those out to kill him. Hersquos been shot twice, beaten, run over and had so many near-death incidents ndash more than a dozen ndash he must be the luckiest man in Walford. The latest teaser has him possibly drown as a party boat on the Thames goes down and the man he thought hersquod murdered is intent on revenge.He wonrsquot die, of course, unless he has a fat contract for another gig in his pocket and it pulls him down. Even so, hersquoll be back in a year or so ndash depend on it. Remember, Dirty Den quite literally came back from the dead after meeting his destiny with the wrong end of a bullet, biding his time in a watery grave for  years before surprising daughter Sharon with his ressurection ndash so anyone can .Phil has a son called Ben, who used to be a nice boy but now hersquos a psycho. Well, itrsquos in the DNA, or large capitals in the script. Ben sets the record for head transplants ndash hersquos now on his sixth one.You can understand that people change as they grow up but Ben is totally transformed, his eyesight has even been cured by his new bonce as he no longer needs those bottle-top specs, and hersquos better looking too. Some nutters have all the luck.Peter Beale, too, is on his sixth incarnation, but this is nothing compared to Sam Mitchell, who had the transplant and then ed in her original head, which must have been kept in a bubbling glass jar for years, although it could have done with a brain transplant. Nevertheless it was a medical miracle.You canrsquot watch an episode now without threats, screams, duplicity, personality disorders, garrottings perhaps, as well, of course, as shape-shting.It never used to be like this in the old days when the high point of an episode of Corrie was Ena Sharples, Minnie Caldwell and Martha Longhurst gossiping in the snug of the Rovers over milk stouts served by Bet Lynch. Although poor Martha went toes up on a an of a heart attack in a dastardly plot departure.Corrie was the first soap to look at working-class le, although it was, and is, a caricature. Prior to this on radio there was Mrs Dalersquos Diary, which I think was about a doctorrsquos we although it could just as well have been about a blowsy dipsomaniac duchess, and The Archers, which is credited with the first soap death when Grace Archer rushed into a burning stable to rescue a horse and was immolated.This was in September  and it was a devious ploy to ert attention from the launch of ITV. It so shocked the nation ndash we were very shockable then ndash that the BBC switchboard was jammed for  hours and Auntie had to plead with people to stop sending wreaths.This was parodied gloriously in an old episode of Hancockrsquos Half Hour called The Bowmans. Hancock plays a bumpkin called Joshua Merriweather who is so unpleasant to the other cast that the character is killed off, only for the BBC to discover the audience loves him, so he is resurrected as his twin brother Benon handsome new wages, and as his revenge he has half the village falling down a disused mine shaft.It hasnrsquot happened yet in Albert Square but itrsquos only  years in so therersquos plenty of time for this and other novel catastrophes. And also for the characters to regenerate like Doctor Who, but, wait a minute hellip!

title: international-scottish-winter-climbing-meet-returns-four-year-absence
story: Climbers from around the world ndash including some of the planetrsquos best ndash have headed to Scotland this week to take part in a special event being revived by Mountaineering Scotland after a four-year absence.To mark the beginning of the ,-strong bodyrsquos th anniversary year, Streap Alba Geamhradh  ndash the International Scottish Winter Climbing Meet ndash is ing for the first time since .Mountaineers from  dferent countries have assembled on the slopes of Scotlandrsquos uplands for a week of climbing which will see them take on classic routes, tackle technical test-pieces and perhaps complete brand new first ascents as they experience the delights of winter climbing in Scotland.Among their number are veterans of Everest and the Greater Ranges, as well as leading Alpinists. But they wonrsquot be staying in cosy chalets, as accommodation will be mountaineers huts ndash ldquobothy-like, in the words of one organiser ndash where home comforts are hard to find.But while the facilities may offer the authentic Scottish climbing experience, nerves have been frayed waiting for the weather to play its part.A relatively warm December and January over Scotlandrsquos high ground had meant that the festival was facing poor conditions in gullies and clfs, which are normally cloaked in the snow and ice that makes them an international draw in winter for the worldrsquos mountaineers.But as the weather worsens for everyone , for the mountaineers conditions are improving as the cold, wind and wet moves in.Simon Richardson, one of Scotlandrsquos foremost winter climbers who sits on the organising committee for the festival, said: ldquoParticipants of the International Winter Meet have been anxiously watching the Scottish weather for several weeks now. After the warm December and January the prospects for winter climbing looked bleak.ldquoFortunately, the February conveyor belt of westerly storms has changed all that. There is plenty of snow across the Highlands, and ice is building rapidly. Ben Nevis and the mountains of Glen Coe are ice-making machines that love frequent blizzards and rapid temperature fluctuations.ldquoThe soft aerated Scottish ice occurs in very few parts of the world and is a delight to climb, and ice climbs in Scotland are highly sought after by International climbers.He added: ldquoThis weather trend looks set to continue through the week of the meet, and winter climbers from both the UK and overseas are looking forward to some superb ice-climbing conditions.The winter meet started in  and ran for  years. The last meet was held by the British Mountaineering Council in , but this yearrsquos revival, led by Mountaineering Scotland, recognises the key role that the event has played on the world mountaineering stage, bringing climbers together to share ideas and form new plans.Richardson said: ldquoThe spin-offs of winter meets have been huge. Regardless of the weather, all the meets have been hugely successful and have become a key event in the mountaineering calendar. International partnerships have formed and climbers have shared techniques and equipment. The meet has also helped shape the ethics of world mountaineering.ldquoAt the turn of this century, dry tooling was all the rage ndash highly gymnastic climbing using ice tool and crampons ndash but these routes required extensive preparation with drilled holds and were protected by bolts.ldquoThe Scottish ethic of climbing routes from the ground up and on sight, and not drilling holes in the rock, was in direct contrast to this and, after visiting Scotland, many visitors understood our ethic and have started to apply this more aesthetic approach in other parts of the world.Partnerships formed on the meets have resulted in dozens of important new routes across the world, and helped push mountaineering to new frontiers.Richardson added: ldquoPerhaps the most striking example of this was the first winter conditions ascent of the North Face of North Twin in the Canadian Rockies [which is] higher and steeper than the Eiger and one of the most formidable alpine walls in the world.ldquoIt was climbed by Steve House of the USA and Marko Prezelj from Slovenia in , where they used Scottish approach. Both climbers met on the Scottish winter meet.ldquoSeveral of the worldrsquos greatest ascents in recent years have derived from partnerships created at the winter meet. The most recent example is the UKrsquos Tom Livingstone and Alescaron Cesen and Luka Stra#ar, both Slovenian, who met on the last winter meet in .ldquoIn August , they made the first ascent of the North Face of Latok I in the Karakoram ndash one of the most coveted prizes in world mountaineering. The route was first attempted in  and had defeated  subsequent expeditions. They were awarded the Piolets drsquoOr, the highest honour in mountaineering, for their ascent.During the week, climbers will stay in some of Scotlandrsquos most famous winter climbing arenas, including the Cairngorms, Lochaber and Glen Coe, being accommodated in mountaineering huts such as the famous Charles Inglis Clark Memorial Hut beneath the massive clfs on the north face of Ben Nevis.The event is being staged with the help of the Scottish Mountaineering Club , the Alpine Club and the British Mountaineering Council, and is sponsored by clothing and equipment manufacturer Salewa.John Fowler, president of the SMC, which owns three of the huts accommodating climbers, said: ldquoThe Scottish Mountaineering Club is delighted to contribute to this international event and welcomes the opportunity to showcase the impressive nature of Scottish winter climbing to some of the best mountaineers from home and abroad.All abilities are represented, with climbers from Israel and South Africa, who have little opportunity to climb snow and ice in their own countries, through to regular winter climbers from Europe, Scandinavia and North America.Host climbers from the UK have been selected to match the abilities of the international mountaineers.These include Paul Ramsden, one of the worldrsquos most accomplished mountaineers and three times winner of the Piolets drsquoOr ndash mountaineeringrsquos highest award.The groups will rotate around each of the locations to ensure everyone gets to experience the ied terrain Scotland can offer.Stuart Younie, chief executive of Mountaineering Scotland, said: ldquoWe want to give the climbers as authentic a Scottish mountaineering experience as possible. In previous years, they would have stayed in a hotel and been based in one place, but here they are staying in the huts right on the doorstep of incredible mountaineering locations.ldquoIrsquod describe the huts as one step up from a bothy. Theyrsquore basic but warm and dry with showers and bunks, offering the type of accommodation any Scottish mountaineer is familiar with.ldquoAnd out on the mountains, we want the groups to experience snow and ice and all the conditions which the country is famous for.Younie added: ldquoA lot of them have told us thatrsquos what theyrsquore here for and wersquore glad it looks like the weather isnrsquot going to disappoint.

title: race-save-music-schools-deacon-blue-star-dougie-vipond-speaks
story: Having gone there specically because of the reputation of music teachers Keith Hamilton and Brian Duguid, he said the encouragement he received and the opportunities he was given ndash all free of charge ndash did not just enhance his le, they shaped it too.ldquoPark Mains had an amazing music department, he said. ldquoIt had jazz bands, orchestras ndash there was something going on every night.ldquoI came from a background where no one had a career in music or would have contemplated a career in music, but going through that school, being under the influence of those teachers and being taken along by their enthusiasm meant that I could go to the RSAMD [now the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland] to study percussion.While that paved the way for him to join a high-profile group that has endured for three decades, it is an opportunity that vanishingly few children are now able to enjoy.According to figures compiled by the Improvement Service, a government-funded organisation whose remit is to help councils ldquoimprove the health, quality of le and opportunities of all people in Scotland, all but six local authorities now charge for instrumental music tuition in schools.That figure is likely to fall to five after Edinburgh City Council this week voted to slash pound, from its music budget.The disparity between what parents across the country are expected to pay is stark, with those in Dundee, Edinburgh, Glasgow, Orkney and Renfrewshire paying nothing at all while at the most extreme end those in Clackmannanshire, West Lothian, the Highlands and East Renfrewshire pay respective annual sums of pound, pound, pound and pound.Nor is there any certainty around what parents within a given local authority area are likely to have to pay, with some councils imposing steady increases over the years, some introducing large, sporadic hikes and others flip-flopping between raising, lowering and eliminating fees.Argyll  Bute and Stirling, for example, have generally raised the cost of music lessons in line with inflation, while North Lanarkshire, which tomorrow will discuss measures that could see its service scrapped completely, has kept its fee-rate static at pound for the past eight years.Midlothian has taken a far more scatter-gun approach, raising its charges incrementally between   and  , before halving them from pound to pound in  . It then charged nothing for two years before last year introducing annual fees of pound. in addition to floating a now-abandoned idea of discontinuing the service.Elsewhere in the Lothians, West Lothian went from charging nothing up to   to imposing fees of pound, while in East Lothian fees went from zero to pound in the same year.The impact this is having on pupil participation has been laid bare in the Improvement Service report, which showed that while overall learner numbers dropped by five per cent between   and the current school year, in some charging authorities they plummeted by close to %.In Aberdeen, where the cost of group lessons has fallen from pound to pound but the cost of inidual tuition has risen from pound to pound, pupil numbers have almost halved from , to ,, although the council said that can be partially explained by a change in the way the data is collected.In West Lothian, meanwhile, learner numbers fell by % year-on-year while in Midlothian they fell by %, and in East Lothian by %.History shows that pupil numbers tend to bounce back in the years following a large drop-off, but concerns have been raised about the impact this is having on the demographics of the children being given the opportunity to learn. Those whose parents can afford to pay and those who are granted a concession because they are in receipt of free school meals tend to fill the spaces, but there is an emerging group of pupils in the middle who are being squeezed out of lessons completely.ldquoTherersquos a chasm in the middle where parents will be choosing between getting their car MOTrsquod or paying for music lessons, said North Lanarkshire percussion teacher Kirk Richardson. ldquoThese are people with jobs, who could pay years ago but now canrsquot afford it.ldquoTherersquos a whole middle section there who wersquore not looking after and thatrsquos the sad bit.Some schools are taking action to ensure that group is not squeezed out completely, with the headteacher at Newbattle High School in Midlothian using general school funds to ensure every childrsquos lessons are paid for them.However, Midlothian woodwind teacher Fiona Gray said that while this is an ldquohonourable thing to do, she noted that it is creating as unlevel a playing field within the local authority area as already exists across council boundaries.ldquoNewbattle is in a catchment where lots of children are falling in the middle and are not eligible for free lessons, she said.ldquoTherersquos a bursary scheme but you have to be below a certain level to get it. A lot of pupils are just above that level but their parents canrsquot afford to pay.ldquoThe headteacher is for very honourable reasons paying for all instrumental lessons for all pupils, which is wonderful, but we donrsquot have an equal and fair playing field for pupils in other schools.In the Western Isles, the Comhairle nan Eilean Siar is also introducing measures designed to ensure its music service can be maintained at as low a cost as possible, with the council currently only charging for lessons in stringed instruments.
